title: [BUFFER/REFACTOR]  byte_offset-> elem_offset, add buffer_bind_scope
body:
- Internally use element_offset instead of byte_offset to represent the offset field
    - This is eaiser for compiler to infer about multple slice
    - DLTensor still takes byte_offset and will be converted correctly
 - Remove extern_op_scope, use buffer_bind_scope instead
 - Add support for op.input_tensors

title: [BUILD/CODEGEN] Allow combine multiple functions in build stage.
body:
## IR Merging
- Enables build take list of LoweredFunc and build a module containing multiple functions

## Object Merging
- For llvm based modules, enable save multiple modules into ```.o``` file, compile a single shared library  and load that single shared library back into one module.
- Still need to investigate how to solve the problem of merging device module binaries
    - Need to combine meta data together.
    - For source code like opencl/metal, simply concat source code is fine.
    - We can also create binary util that emits multiple device modules as opposed to a single one.

title: [BUILD] Enable RTTI of most part of library, example extension pkg.
body:
Most of C++ library compiles with RTTI enabled. LLVM by default compiles with ```fno-rtti```. This creates some trouble of direct linking tvm from existing libraries which need RTTI.

This PR tries to resolve this issue by
- Compile the llvm related code with ```fno-rtti```
- Compile other code with RTTI enabled
- Because Internally TVM interacts with LLVM related module via minimum interface (Module) codegen, in theory this could work as long as TVM resolve this cross linking issue.

The assumption is that ```no-rtti``` code can still inheritate and use data structure from code compiled with rtti, (this is true as long as the vtable data structure is the same). Note that it is not possible other way around. I have tested this under linux.

repo.name: tvm
repo.description: Open deep learning compiler stack for cpu, gpu and specialized accelerators

title: [CODEGEN/RUNTIME] Cross Compile Test
body:
This PR gives a basic example for cross compile test workflow, see https://github.com/tqchen/tvm/blob/master/tests/python/unittest/test_codegen_cross_llvm.py#L34

The workflow
- Compile TVM with runtime only on the target board
   - Add ```BUILD_TARGETS = lib/libtvm_runtime.so``` to config.mk
   - Add TVM_USE_RUNTIME_LIB=1 to environment variable
   - ```python -m tvm.exec.rpc_server```
- Build target with specific flag
- Save the .o file to the path
- Upload the .o file to the remote RPC server, this case it is an arm board
    - In this example we do the shared library creation on remote use gcc
    - Optionally, we can use local cross compile tool to generate the .so file, and upload the shared library
- Use tvm rpc to run the tests

title: [RUNTIME] RPC runtime that support run testing on remote device.
body:
In many scenarios we want to target devices that do not necessarily have a TVM compiler stack, for example arm board or phones. In these cases, we still want to automate the test-flows in the same way we did for gpus. RPC runtime is used to solve this problem.

- The target environment only need to have tvm runtime and rpc server, which is minimum
- We run compiler on a host server, connect to the target board, and run tests on the target board

Example workflow, see also https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/tests/python/unittest/test_runtime_rpc.py

```python
import tvm
from tvm.contrib import rpc

def test_remote():
    # build the code locally
    n = tvm.convert(1024)
    A = tvm.placeholder((n,), name='A')
    B = tvm.compute(A.shape, lambda *i: A(*i) + 1.0, name='B')
    s = tvm.create_schedule(B.op)
    f = tvm.build(s, [A, B], target_of_board_arch, name="myadd")
    f.export_library("mylib.so")
    # connect to remote server
    remote = rpc.connect(board_url, board_port)
    ctx = remote.cpu(0)
    # upload and run on remote
    remote.upload("mylib.so")
    f1 = remote.load_module("mylib.so")
    a = tvm.nd.array(np.random.uniform(size=1024).astype(A.dtype), ctx)
    b = tvm.nd.array(np.zeros(1024, dtype=A.dtype), ctx)
    f1(a, b)
    # verify on local server
    np.testing.assert_equal(b.asnumpy(), a.asnumpy() + 1)
```

title: check attach_stage & group in schedule.copy()
body:
```python
import tvm                                                                                                                                                                 

n = tvm.var("n")
m = tvm.var("m")
A = tvm.placeholder((n, m), name='A')
k = tvm.reduce_axis((0, m), "k")
 
B = tvm.compute((n,), lambda i: tvm.sum(A[i, k], axis=k), name="B")
sb = tvm.create_schedule(B.op)
 
C = tvm.compute(A.shape, lambda i,j: A[i][j] * 2, name="C")
sc = tvm.create_schedule(C.op)
 
sc[C].compute_at(sb[B], B.op.axis[0])
print(tvm.lower(sc, [A, B, C], simple_mode=True))
```

The codes above can crash the process with useless error message:

```
TVM: Initializing cython mode...
libc++abi.dylib: terminating with uncaught exception of type std::out_of_range: unordered_map::at: key not found
Abort trap: 6
```

title: [MODULE/DSO] Support pack everything into one shared library.
body:
previously, we need to save the device module and host file separately, this PR enables us to pack everything into one shared library via Module.export_library

Under the hood, we use a PackImportsToC to pack the device related things into binary blob, and embed that blob in a c file via
```c
extern const char __tvm_dev_mblob[] =  {0x0, 0x11, ....};
extern const unsigned __tvm_dev_mblob_nbytes = number of bytes in the blob.
```
During DSO module loading, these symbols are detected and the device module are automatically loaded 

https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/issues/124

title: [CODEGEN/PASS] Improve callpacked lowering, allow pass array callback.
body:
Allocate the function local stacks at beginning of the call. 

Allow pass buffer to call_packed, which will translate to a callback with a corresponding array, this allows us to use call backs to do interesting things such as inspecting the content.

title: [DEV/IR] Python IRBuilder
body:
https://github.com/tqchen/tvm/issues/67

```python
ib = tvm.ir_builder.create()
n = tvm.var("n")
A = ib.allocate("float32", n, name="A")
with ib.for_range(0, n, name="i") as i:
    with ib.if_scope(tvm.make.EQ(i % 2, 0)):
        A[i] = A[i] + 1
# The result stmt.
stmt = ib.get()
```
